I think that‚Äôs all you can really do but maybe some others will have better advice.

I think oftentimes we want to know that we can help other people with hard-earned advice gleaned from our own painful life experiences. Because sometimes that at least gives those lessons a meaning other than just to hurt. 

I think there‚Äôs a great deal of just general humanity in being concerned enough to devote time and energy into helping complete strangers with their heaviest life problems and even if they don‚Äôt listen to the advice now, it doesn‚Äôt mean it won‚Äôt sink in and be something they heed later down the line. 

We frequently already know the other person is right but can‚Äôt accept it yet because the truth is so painful. 

Sadly, you can‚Äôt instill self worth and esteem into someone else for them; it‚Äôs something they have to realize on their own. We all learn in our own time & on our own paths. You‚Äôve done the best you could for them and that‚Äôs commendable. 

It is frustrating to see good people ignore good advice. But don‚Äôt be dismayed if your good advice doesn‚Äôt seem to make an immediate dent. It doesn‚Äôt mean it never will. 

Of course, there‚Äôs always the option to just not reply; and that may be the best one for you too. 

I think it‚Äôs great that you care so much about these people. Many of them have shitty self esteem because no one ever did.

NAD- have you seen an endocrinologist & had your thyroid checked out? A GP typically doesn‚Äôt understand the nuance needed to correctly interpret the labs so I suggest going to an endo for that instead of anyone else. 

My thyroid was jacked up for yearssss and I didn‚Äôt know it (neither did my docs because the labs always came back normal); but the tumors I had would cause sporadic fluctuations between hyper and hypothyroid symptoms, along with a TON of other vague ones. Like sudden, AWFUL adult-onset cystic acne; joint pain; extreme lethargy; weird rashes; extreme weight loss/gain; and many others I can‚Äôt even remember at this point. 

Thyroid and endocrine misfires will fuck your shit up. 

I doubt a doc would just write up an order for generalized/non-specific imaging studies (like full body MRIs or something)... but an unrelated MRI was actually the only way anyone knew there was a problem w my thyroid. Just coincidental. 


Also, have you had a Lyme panel? Even if it came back negative, would they be open to prescribing you a course of doxy to see if it makes any improvement? (since the Lyme tests often come back with false negatives from what I understand). I don‚Äôt know if that‚Äôs a thing or not, but over the years I‚Äôve heard of people doctor and veterinarians doing the same even with a neg Lyme panel.  

Hopefully some of this is helpful. I‚Äôm sorry OP, I KNOW how frustrating and scary this is. I had a number of doctors look at me and roll their eyes over the course of a decade because they felt that my symptoms were all a result of my mental health issues (depression, anxiety, and what they initially Dx‚Äôd as Bipolar II but ended up actually being Borderline Personality Disorder).  

I wish you all the best OP.
